ProjectTitle: Making the Good Reader and Citizen: The History of Literature Instruction in American Schools
AllDisciplines: American Studies; Literature, General; U.S. History
ProjectDesc:
A two-week seminar for 16 English teachers (grades 6-12) on the history of literature instruction in the twentieth century. 

A 2-week seminar with a target audience of 6-12th grade educators that puts the present-day teaching of English in conversation with its past by exploring the history of literature instruction in the United States, especially its role in preparing students for citizenship.

Participants: Jared Farmer (Project Director: January 2016 to March 2019)
GranteeDisplay:
Jared Farmer
SUNY Research Foundation, Stony Brook (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
ProjectTitle: The Latest Oldest Tree: Survival Stories for a Time of Extinction
AllDisciplines: History of Science; History, General; Interdisciplinary Studies, General
ProjectDesc:
A meditation on the challenges that humans face in thinking about long spans of time, the book narrates the history of various searches for the oldest living tree in the world and explains the scientific developments that enable us to measure extreme biological age.

The oldest trees have lasted longer than any civilization. Determining the location and age of these biological record holders is a modern fixation. In my book, I’ll narrate the never-ending search for the oldest living tree in the world, as definitions of “oldest” and “living” and “tree” and “world” have changed over time. I’ll examine individual and clonal longevity, and the tools--including dendrochronology and radiocarbon dating--scientists have developed to measure extreme biological age. Along the way, I’ll ponder scientific-cum-philosophical questions: What does it mean to be young and old? Living and dead? Without minimizing the global environmental crisis, my project stresses persistence amid loss, devotion amid destruction. Arboreal survival stories are vital for contemplating the future of oldness in an anthropogenic epoch.

Participants: Daniela Flesler (Project Director: April 2016 to March 2019)
GranteeDisplay:
Daniela Flesler
SUNY Research Foundation, Stony Brook (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
ProjectTitle: The Memory Work of Sepharad: New Inheritances for 21st-Century Spain
ProjectDesc:
Completion of a book-length study of how modern Spain is addressing and developing its Jewish history.

My book project studies the long-ranging implications of the current “re-discovery” of Spain’s Jewish past. Since the mid 1980s, many cultural and political initiatives have engaged with the memory of Jewish Spain and attempted to officially reconnect Spain with the Jewish world. Today, all things Sepharad are widely marketed throughout Spain, from cultural festivals, museums, former synagogues and Jewish quarters, to historical novels, travel guides, music and cookbooks. The 2015 Law granting Spanish nationality to the descendants of Jews expelled in 1492 is the latest example of this phenomenon. The broad public circulation of new narratives that are putting Spanish Jews at their center has the potential to produce profound social transformations. The book explores the ways in which the memory of Sepharad has allowed Spaniards to rethink long-established notions of cultural identity within the recent debates over Spain's historical memory.

Participants: Eliza J Reilly (Project Director: December 2016 to July 2018)
GranteeDisplay:
SUNY Research Foundation, Stony Brook (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
Eliza J Reilly (Project Director: December 2016 to July 2018)
ProjectTitle: Algorithms and Us
ProgramName: Cooperative Agreements and Special Projects (Public Programs)
ProjectDesc: The proposed project is a symposium “Algorithms and Us” to be held in late spring 2017 at Stony Brook University. The convening of experts and educators from the humanities, social sciences and STEM fields, will explore, from the perspective of the humanities, the expanding technological phenomenon of “big data” and its impact on our social economic, political, and emotional lives. While the collection of personal data affects nearly every aspect of contemporary life, general knowledge and awareness of how this data is analyzed and used lags far behind the technology and its ethical, social, and civic implications are relatively obscure to most people. The outcome of this cross-disciplinary convening will be to identify potential resources, texts, models, and formats for future programming that would illuminate and investigate this phenomenon for the public.

Participants: James H. Rubin (Project Director: March 2015 to March 2017)
GranteeDisplay:
James H. Rubin
SUNY Research Foundation, Stony Brook (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
ProjectTitle: Why Monet Matters, or Meanings Among the Lily Pads
AllDisciplines: Aesthetics; Art History and Criticism; Cultural History
ProjectDesc:
The writing of a book placing the well-known art of a popular artist in literary, cultural, historical, and philosophical context to deepen understanding and appreciation of modern art in general.

Few painters are as famous as the great French Impressionist Claude Monet. He is a staple of the museum exhibition circuit, and few masters bring higher prices. His house and gardens in France, with their placid lily ponds, are among the most visited sites in Europe. Using this popularity to attract the widest audience, the book will offer ways of thinking beyond surfaces when looking at modern art. Monet’s Water Lilies appear above all to be a call to visual experience. Their scale and aesthetic presence suspend thoughts of the outside world and its conflicts. Yet when one realizes that these works were made in a period of social and political turmoil-regime changes, the Dreyfus Affair, and WW I—questions must arise about the context—personal, cultural, and historical—in which an artist creates such sumptuous fantasies of nature. By revealing those conditions, it is possible show how Monet’s work—a harbinger of American abstraction—appeals to something deep in modern consciousness.

Participants: Eva Feder Kittay (Project Director: May 2013 to August 2015)
GranteeDisplay:
Eva Feder Kittay
SUNY Research Foundation, Stony Brook (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
ProjectTitle: Philosophy and Cognitive Disability
ProjectDesc: Historical and contemporary philosophical accounts of persons, both with respect to what is due them (justice, an adequate level of care, full citizenship) and with respect to what is conducive to their good (requirements for well-being and a meaningful life), have given short shrift to individuals with significant cognitive disabilities. As a philosopher and a parent of a child with severe cognitive disabilities, the contradictions between philosophically normative conceptions of the human and those I have formed in my experiences with my disabled daughter have cried out for a resolution. The project, which will issue in a book, asks us to consider how certain traditional and contemporary questions in philosophy are reframed when we include people with serious cognitive disabilities within the scope of the inquiry and urges that actual relationships of care and love undermine a priori certitudes and thus enlarges our vision of who we are.

Participants: Lawrence Frohman (Project Director: September 2013 to March 2015)
GranteeDisplay:
Lawrence Frohman
SUNY Research Foundation, Stony Brook (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
ProjectTitle: Surveillance, Privacy and the Politics of Personal Information in West Germany, 1960-1990
ProjectDesc: Surveillance and privacy are two of the primary concepts through which we seek to make sense of modernity and of a world in which virtually all forms of social interaction are now digitally mediated. They have already become--and are certain to remain--two of the most contentious policy issues of our age. From 1960 to 1990 West Germany pioneered both the use of new information technologies and computer privacy laws to regulate the processing of personal information. I argue that during these years the systematization of population surveillance gave rise to a new form of social politics, the politics of personal information, to new discourses on privacy, which became the primary means of theorizing the expansion of such surveillance, and to a corresponding privacy-based social movement. What can these precocious West German developments tell us about privacy, surveillance, and social power in modern information societies?

Giuseppe Gerbino (Co Project Director: November 2010 to September 2014)
ProjectTitle: Online Edition of the Secular Music of Luca Marenzio
ProjectDesc:
Preparation for publication of volumes 4, 8, 13, 19, and 21 of the complete online digital edition of the secular music of Luca Marenzio. (33 months)

The goal of the Marenzio Online Digital Edition (MODE) is to make available, for the first time, the complete critical edition of the secular music of Luca Marenzio (c. 1553-1599), a preeminent composer of the Renaissance whose output had a fundamental impact on early modern European culture. By innovatively integrating music philology and digital technology, MODE introduces a model for both producing and disseminating editions of musical repertories of the Western tradition. The comparison of the sources through new digital tools allows editors not only to produce an accurate version of a composition and to enormously speed up the editing process, but also to improve scholarly understanding about the world of early modern printing. The output of the edition through a dynamic web-based digital interface offers users the flexibility well known to other humanities digital editions, but thus far unavailable to music. The NEH grant will be used to edit one fourth of the works.

Participants: William C. Chittick (Project Director: May 2009 to October 2011)
GranteeDisplay:
William C. Chittick
SUNY Research Foundation, Stony Brook (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
ProjectTitle: Divine and Human Love in the Islamic Tradition
ProgramName: Fellowships for College Teachers and Independent Scholars
ProjectDesc: I plan to write a substantial book, arranged thematically, that will describe the role of love in Islamic thought and culture from the earliest period down into the nineteenth century. The narrative will be interspersed with detailed quotations from the most seminal theologians, philosophers, and mystics and will be seasoned with selections from Arab and Persian poets. The text will be aimed at undergraduates and general readers; ample apparatus, including a comprehensive index, will make it a useful tool for graduate students and scholars. Themes that will be illustrated in depth include God as love, God's love for creation generally and human beings specifically, human love for God, human love for creation and other human beings, love as the force that brings the universe into existence and then closes the gap between God and human beings, and love as the energy that establishes human perfection on the moral, ethical, and spiritual planes.

Participants: Barbara E. Frank (Project Director: May 2009 to November 2012)
GranteeDisplay:
Barbara E. Frank
SUNY Research Foundation, Stony Brook (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
ProjectTitle: Marks of Identity: Reconstructing the History of an African Ceramic Tradition
ProgramName: Fellowships for College Teachers and Independent Scholars
ProjectDesc: This proposal seeks support for field research and time to complete a monograph on a remarkable group of women of the Folona region of southern Mali whose identity and artistry as potters provide clues to their complex history. My approach combines analyses of the formal qualities of pottery and the technological styles of ceramic production with the study of gender, artisan caste, language, and local histories within a regional perspective. Although they speak a Mande language and identify the Mande heartland as their ancestral home, the kinds of pots these women make, the way they form and fire them, and their identity as the wives of griot-leatherworkers rather than of blacksmiths suggests that the origins of this ceramic tradition may lie elsewhere. At the heart of my project is a desire for the ceramic arts of Africa to be recognized as art forms worthy of scholarly attention and for African women to be recognized as bearers of cultural heritage in their own right.

Participants: Kiyoteru Tsutsui (Project Director: May 2007 to November 2009)
GranteeDisplay:
Kiyoteru Tsutsui
Regents of the University of Michigan (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
Institution: Regents of the University of Michigan
ProjectTitle: Global Human Rights and the Transformation of Minority Politics in Contemporary Japan
ProgramName: Fellowships for Advanced Social Science Research on Japan
ProjectDesc: This book project examines how the rise of global human rights in the last few decades has transformed minority politics, giving rise to political activism by disadvantaged ethnic minorities in many corners of the world. Focusing on three minority social movements in Japan, Ainu people, Korean residents and the Burakumin, the project illustrates how the global human rights regime has provided new venues for contestation for minorities, growing flows of mobilizational resources for disadvantaged groups, and new vocabularies for framing their claims. These processes led to greater activism by all three minority groups in Japan, although the influence varied according to their historical backgrounds. Further, the movements all contribute back to the global political arena and elevated global human rights standards, demonstrating a feedback loop to the global regime. The book presents detailed accounts of these processes, using archival documents and interviews as main data sources.

Participants: Bonnie Gordon (Project Director: May 2005 to September 2008)
GranteeDisplay:
Bonnie Gordon
University of Virginia (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
ProjectTitle: Voice Machines: The Castrato, the Cat Piano, and Other Strange Sounds
ProjectDesc: Produced by surgical alteration and rigorous training, castrati represented stunning feats of early modern technology and art. Their stunted but muscular vocal cords resonated through expanded ribs. Perfected with rigorous training, these voices animated the most astonishing vocal ornamentation of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. This project considers the castrato's voice as an artifically manipulated natural phenomenon that played out musically the contemporaneous melding of science and art, technology and nature. The ambiguities resulting from the early modern fascination with such meldings provides historical context for the intense pleasure castrati brought to audiences of that time.

Participants: Christina Y. Bethin (Project Director: May 2005 to July 2007)
GranteeDisplay:
Christina Y. Bethin
SUNY Research Foundation, Stony Brook (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
ProjectTitle: The Form and Function of Prominence in Slavic Languages
ProjectDesc: Prominence is central to distinguishing words in languages, and it is usually described as a convergence of certain properties (stress, tone, high pitch, or vowel length) on a given syllable. In Slavic languages, however, these properties do not always converge on the obvious prominent position in a word and thus Slavic presents a compelling case for studying prominence. This project focuses on the stress-based Slavic languages and specifically on the phonology and morphology of their unstressed syllables in order to determine exactly how prominence functions and how it changed over time.

Participants: Elizabeth C. Stone (Project Director: June 2005 to April 2007)
GranteeDisplay:
SUNY Research Foundation, Stony Brook (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
Elizabeth C. Stone (Project Director: June 2005 to April 2007)
ProjectTitle: Remote Sensing and GIS Training and Research for Iraqi Archaeologists
ProjectDesc:
An intensive training program for two faculty members each from Baghdad and Mosul Universities and two members of the Iraqi State Board of Antiquities and Heritage in remote sensing and geographic information systems (GIS).

This project focuses on a four-month training program in Remote Sensing and GIS for professional Iraqi archaeologists drawn from the State Board of Antiquities and Baghdad and Mosul Universities. The course will focus on the utility of these techniques for research, site protection and site management. By the end of the program, the faculty will have the skills to teach these materials on their return to Iraq. Coincident with the training program, we will survey archaeological sites in the key Nippur, Uruk and Eridu survey areas using recent high resolution Digital Globe imagery for evidence of site damage from looting and development, recording new sites, ancient landscape features and intra-site details.

Participants: Jane Cicely Sugarman (Project Director: May 2004 to August 2006)
GranteeDisplay:
Jane Cicely Sugarman
SUNY Research Foundation, Stony Brook (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
ProjectTitle: Albanian Commercial Musics and the Dilemmas of Representation
ProjectDesc: A book on the transnational Albanian commercial music industry and its role in the constitution of contemporary forms of Albanian identity, based on field research conducted in North America, Western Europe, and the former Yugoslavia. Contemporary Albanians long to integrate themselves into the high modernity of the West without losing a sense of themselves as a distinctive social group. The book will focus upon the dilemmas faced by Albanians, and indeed by many other communities outside the historic West, when they attempt to create cultural forms that are both locally distinctive and recognizeably "modern": dilemmas that I attribute to contradictory tendencies within the notion of modernity itself.

Participants: Sachiko Murata (Project Director: May 2003 to March 2006)
GranteeDisplay:
Sachiko Murata
SUNY Research Foundation, Stony Brook (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
ProjectTitle: An Analysis of Liu Chih's "T'ien-fang hsing-li"
ProjectDesc: T'ien-fang hsing-li ("Nature-and-Principle according to Islam") by Liu Chiu, first published in the year 1704, is the most important exposition of Islamic teachings in the Chinese language and one of the most fascinating examples of civilizational dialogue in pre-modern times. Having completed the translation of the book into English, I propose to carry out a thorough study of the Islamic and Chinese backgrounds along with a careful analysis of the ideas in the light of Islamic and Neoconfucian thought.

Participants: Sara Lipton (Project Director: September 2002 to February 2004)
GranteeDisplay:
Sara Lipton
SUNY Research Foundation, Stony Brook (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
ProjectTitle: Preaching, Art, and Piety in the High Middle Ages (1150-1350)
ProjectDesc: My project explores the intersection of two important new forms of Christian instruction in the High Middle Ages: popular preaching and Gothic art. I shall analyze references to or invocations of art in four distinct groups of sermons from 1150-1350. These clusters provide evidence with which to assess and contrast the ways in which clerical elites, lay elites, and lay masses viewed works of art, and allow such "ways of seeing" to be situated within the context of contemporary thought and society. This project will contribute to the current re-thinking of religious experience and response, and illuminate how new modes of communication and expression influenced the nature of high medieval Christianity.

ProjectDesc: Study is part of a continuing investigation into the processes of generation and dissemination of music in the Middle Ages. Study addresses itself to the phenomenology of the music, its composition, and performance, and the role of notation in both processes. Focus will be on the transmission of tropes and of Parisian organum.

GranteeDisplay:
David R. Sheehan
SUNY Research Foundation, Stony Brook (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
ProjectTitle: The Poetry of Jonathan Swift
ProjectDesc: To examine the methods and purposes of Jonathan Swift's public political poetry, and to compare his achievement with that of other poets writing on the same events and personalities. The major poems of Swift's later career will also be examined to demonstrate the ways Swift merges social verse and political modes of poetry. Only recently has Swift's poetry begun to receive scholarly and critical attention; this project is part of a book-length study of Swift as a major 18th century poet.

ProjectTitle: A Center for Photographic Images of Medicine and Health Care
PrimaryDiscipline: History and Philosophy of Science, Technology, and Medicine
AllDisciplines: History and Philosophy of Science, Technology, and Medicine
ProjectDesc:
To establish a center for the collection cataloging, and dissemination of slide reproductions on health care history for teaching purposes at different educational levels.

To establish a center to collect and catalogue photographic images of medicine and health care and to disseminate slide reproductions of such images to educators. Images will be catalogued according to photographic criteria, after the development of a useable iconography as a methodological tool. Tentative topics for slide sets include "Images of Women in Medicine."

Participants: Sarah Fuller (Project Director: June 1976 to present)
GranteeDisplay:
Sarah Fuller
SUNY Research Foundation, Stony Brook (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
ProjectTitle: Medieval Discant Theory
ProjectDesc: To clarify the nature of medieval discant theory in music, aid in its teaching and to demonstrate the extent to which discant precepts may illuminate principles of organization and structure in medieval polyphony. The study will treat medieval discant theory from its beginnings to circa 1400 being chiefly concerned with the emergence of a theory of discant, the nature of discant teaching, that is whether it appears to be a matter of universal precept or of local practice, the extent to which it may or may not follow a directed path of development and the relation of discant teaching to musical composition, the degree to which musical practice and discant teaching appear to be interconnected and the application of discant principles in the analysis of medieval music.

Clifford C. Huffman
SUNY Research Foundation, Stony Brook (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
ProjectTitle: John Wolfe (1547-1601): Life and Works
ProjectDesc: To complete research of John Wolfe s printings of seven texts of geographical exploration dealing with the search of a Northeast passage to the New World, showing how Wolfe reflected the diverse community living in London at the height of the Elizabethan age. John Wolfe ran a major printing shop in London 1579 - 1601.

GranteeDisplay:
John R. Logan
SUNY Research Foundation, Stony Brook (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
ProjectTitle: Rural Political Movments in Early Twentieth Century Spain
ProjectDesc: To study the two main forms of rural political movements in Spain prior to the Civil War of 1936 - 1939. The nature of the movements the anarchist CNT and the socialist UGT and FNTT, can be understood in terms of the structure of society and politics in the regions in which each developed.

Participants: Frederick E. Brown (Project Director: January 1976 to present)
GranteeDisplay:
Frederick E. Brown
SUNY Research Foundation, Stony Brook (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
ProjectTitle: The Theology of Urbanism Paris, 1760-1870
ProjectDesc: To examine the theological implications surrounding the urbanist projects of Paris from 1760 to 1870. The notion of Louis Napoleon during the 1850's,that Paris was the re-embodiment of Rome, will be examined--its roots and the reasons for its rise. The study will contribute to our understanding of the origins of totalitarianism its aesthetic symbols, its ways of arranging human space and time.

Participants: John A. Williams (Project Director: June 1974 to present)
GranteeDisplay:
John A. Williams
SUNY Research Foundation, Stony Brook (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
ProjectTitle: Non-European Societies and British Colonial Rule: A Comparative Study
ProjectDesc: To determine the position of non-European inhabitants in the regions dominated by expanding Europe in the nineteenth century. The approach will proceed through a series of case studies of both settler and non-settler regions. The study considers the timing, nature, and extent of European impact as well as the non-European socieities' responses.

Participants: Richard L. Levin (Project Director: September 1974 to present)
GranteeDisplay:
Richard L. Levin
SUNY Research Foundation, Stony Brook (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
ProjectTitle: A Critical Examination of Recent Trends in the Re-Interpretation of English Drama
AllDisciplines: British Literature; Literary Criticism; Theater History and Criticism
ProjectDesc: To examine recent trends in criticism which have been producing various reinterpretations of the drama of certain major playwrights of the English Renaissance. The focus is on 3 main trends 1) analysis in terms of a "central theme," 2) the discovery of ironies undercutting the play's values, 3) insistence that play's meaning is deduced from attitudes held by the original audience. A systematic critique of this nature, which is reevaluating interpretations of English drama at its high point, is a significant contribution to the literary field.

This tradition can help us to understanding our own social and cultural problems and their human foundations.

Participants: Anthony I. Rizzuto (Project Director: June 1970 to present)
GranteeDisplay:
Anthony I. Rizzuto
SUNY Research Foundation, Stony Brook (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
ProjectTitle: The Style and Themes of Alfred de Musset's La Confession d'un enfant du siecle
ProjectDesc: Study of the style and themes of Alfred de Musset's La Confession d'un enfant du siecle. Criticisms of the author's personality and aesthetic attitudes have obscured the psychological and political themes of the novel. Fellow hopes that a textual analysis will show its relevance to the present generation and restore it to its proper place among the prose masterpieces of the nineteenth century.

Participants: Norman O. Jung (Project Director: September 1970 to present)
GranteeDisplay:
SUNY Research Foundation, Stony Brook (Stony Brook, NY 11794-0001)
Norman O. Jung (Project Director: September 1970 to present)
ProjectTitle: Faculty-Student Development Team in History
ProjectDesc: Faculty-student team to develop new resources for an experimental introductory course in history. New approach to study of history centered around research project introductory course to introduce student to historical documents and methods. Faculty-student team to develop new resources for an experimental introductory course in history. Jointly sponsored by Frank Melville Memorial Library and Department of History. Team composed of two P.I.'s (on head reference librarian, the other professor of history), two members of library staff, two graduate students and six undergraduates. New approach to study of history-student-teacher investigating teams work together, using library resources, on a research project. Student gains experience in use of historical archives and original documents and in different kinds of historical writings. Success of such a course depends on the body of materials researched. Team to develop two or three such units for source materials for course use and outline entire procedure for course from assembly of materials to introduction of materials and research methods to students. Project designed to constructively channel the desire of college students to participate in the creation of curricula and to play a guiding role in their own education. Trains students members of team to develop teaching units of primary source materials and to uncover significant historical resources in the community; exposes them to sources usually introduced on the graduate level. Funds for salaries, consultant, supplies, travel (local), and communication.
